image.altText: People wearing various uniforms, one saying UN, standing in front of a truck with boxes on board

items.synopsis: The UN says the second convoy of aid trucks which have gone into Gaza only accounts for "about 3 per cent of the daily average volume" of supplies the area received before fresh hostilities. Follow live.

title.children: UN says latest aid trucks 'about 3 per cent' of Gaza's pre-war daily supplies

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin say the United States expects the Israel-Gaza war to escalate through involvement by proxies of Iran. They asserted that the Biden administration is prepared to respond if American personnel or armed forces become the target of any such hostilities. "This is not what we want, not what we're looking for. We don't want escalation," Mr Blinken said. "We don't want to see our forces or our personnel come under fire. But if that happens, we're ready for it." Mr Austin, echoed the sentiment saying "what we're seeing is a prospect of a significant escalation of attacks on our troops and our people throughout the region." He said the US has the right to self-defense "and we won't hesitate to take the appropriate action." Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh and Iranian Foreign Minister Hossein Amirabdollahian discussed the means of stopping the Israeli "brutal crimes" in the besieged Gaza enclave, the group said in a statement late Sunday. AP/Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: High-ranking US officials: US prepared to respond if it becomes a target

children.content: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin say the United States expects the Israel-Gaza war to escalate through involvement by proxies of Iran.
They asserted that the Biden administration is prepared to respond if American personnel or armed forces become the target of any such hostilities.
"This is not what we want, not what we're looking for. We don't want escalation," Mr Blinken said.
"We don't want to see our forces or our personnel come under fire. But if that happens, we're ready for it."
Mr Austin, echoed the sentiment saying "what we're seeing is a prospect of a significant escalation of attacks on our troops and our people throughout the region."
He said the US has the right to self-defense "and we won't hesitate to take the appropriate action."

Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh and Iranian Foreign Minister Hossein Amirabdollahian discussed the means of stopping the Israeli "brutal crimes" in the besieged Gaza enclave, the group said in a statement late Sunday.
AP/Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Gaza's most crowded United Nations relief shelter is currently sheltering around 21,000 people, according to the UN's latest update. "The number of [displaced people] per shelter has reached in many shelters 4,400," the update says, adding the buildings were "designed to host 1,500-2,000". It also notes "entire neighbourhoods" have been destroyed in the Gaza Strip since October 7. "The Gaza Ministry of Public Works reported the destruction of 15,749 housing units and the rendering of 10,935 housing units uninhabitable, as of 21 October," it says. "Another 142,500 housing units sustained minor to moderate damage. " The total number of housing units destroyed or damaged accounts for at least 43 per cent of all housing units in the Gaza Strip."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 43 per cent of Gaza's homes destroyed as thousands search for shelter

children.content: Gaza's most crowded United Nations relief shelter is currently sheltering around 21,000 people, according to the UN's latest update.
"The number of [displaced people] per shelter has reached in many shelters 4,400," the update says, adding the buildings were "designed to host 1,500-2,000".

props.alt: A graph showing the number of destroyed buildings split into lightly damaged, severely damaged and uninhabitable, and destroyed

children.content: (United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs)
It also notes "entire neighbourhoods" have been destroyed in the Gaza Strip since October 7.
"The Gaza Ministry of Public Works reported the destruction of 15,749 housing units and the rendering of 10,935 housing units uninhabitable, as of 21 October," it says.
"Another 142,500 housing units sustained minor to moderate damage.
" The total number of housing units destroyed or damaged accounts for at least 43 per cent of all housing units in the Gaza Strip."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The 14 trucks that entered Gaza today account for "about 3 per cent of the daily average volume " of supplies the area received before fresh hostilities flared, according to the United Nations. The aid marks "another glimmer of hope", the organisation said in its latest update, but called for fuel supplies to be allowed in "immediately". "Aid deliveries entering Gaza have not included fuel," the report said. "UNRWA, by far the largest humanitarian provider in Gaza, will exhaust its fuel reserves within the next three days."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: UN says latest trucks 'about 3 per cent' of Gaza's pre-war daily supplies

The aid marks "another glimmer of hope",
the organisation said in its latest update, but called for fuel supplies to be allowed in "immediately".
"Aid deliveries entering Gaza have not included fuel," the report said.
"UNRWA, by far the largest humanitarian provider in Gaza, will exhaust its fuel reserves within the next three days."

title.children: Emergency warnings issued for fast-moving fires in southern Queensland

items.synopsis: As the climate changes, an increasing number of houses in Australia are projected to be exposed to bushfires. Now, a new tool, flagged by a royal commission, has been developed that lets individuals and communities realise their vulnerabilities, plan for change and go into the next disaster better prepared.

title.children: 'I wish I'd made my house resilient for far less money': How to build a house that can survive extreme weather

image.altText: A man looks at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

items.synopsis: The Israel-Gaza war helped send US 10-year bond rates within a whisker of 5 per cent on Friday, leaving Wall Street in the red every session last week, with the ASX again following. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX continues slide as Israel-Gaza war worries see bond interest rates push higher

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Medibank has become the latest company to explore a shorter working week, announcing 250 of its employees will take part in a six-month trial of a four-day work week. The private health insurer says the trial, designed with 4 Day Week Global and monitored by Macquarie University, is part of their wider commitment to be "the healthiest workplace in Australia". Workers involved in Medibank's trial will experiment with the 100:80:100 model — where employees and bosses agree to 100% of their previous pay, for 80% of the work time, while committing to 100% productivity. For full-time Medibank employees, it means they only work four days a week, while part-time employees are pro-rated. "There are lots of pressures out there right now, whether it's cost of living or people managing their work and home commitments," Medibank's Kylie Bishop said. "We're constantly thinking about how we can help balance that for our people and invest in their health and wellbeing to help prevent issues like burnout." Medibank's four-day week trial comes as Unilever, which makes consumer goods like Rexona, Streets and Dove, is about to wind down its year-long trial next month that around 500 employees took part in. Curious about the four-day work week? You can read more about it (and the push to expand it) below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Medibank to trial four-day working week

featuredLink.title: Four-day week enshrined in first Australian union agreement, with concept spreading

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: That's according to a new report from the EU Tax Observatory, which has found profit shifting by multinational firms deprived Australia's Treasury of almost $11 billion in 2020. It's part of a system that is depriving governments all over the world of much needed funds — and the report suggests Australians hold more than $370 billion in known tax havens, where they pay only minimal tax. Although changes to bank secrecy laws are having an impact on tax avoidance, there is more Australia could to do, and the report itself is calling for a global minimum tax rate for billionaires. You can hear more about this landmark report and what recommendations it's made from business reporter Daniel Ziffer below : If you don't have time to watch the key takeaways, don't stress — you can also give it a read below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 📺 Australians are holding more than $370 billion in foreign tax havens
